Social Engineering for Good, Not Evil

Because it's not just about the tech

Scott Nonnenberg

github.com/scottnonnenberg/social-engineering-for-good

The Divide

  • Between tech and non-tech
  • Frustrations on both sides
  • One of the first images in a google image search for "Business"
  • Why are these nauseatingly bland business images so common?

People matter

  • They are as importrant to your career than your tech skill
  • Business is people interacting
  • Your job, Your family, Your life - people interacting

Why me?

Well, I have an interesting history in the tech world...
  • I was this guy! There's a reason there aren't many pictures remaining of me from high school
  • Discovered computer games at age 8
  • Family wasn't technical, always encouraging me to spend less time on the computer (guilt complex!)
  • Called a geek or brain in school
  • Found my place: working at HP doing web dev in High school
  • College was better yet: Computer Science at CalPoly
  • Call out of the blue from recruiter, "What's a Program Manager?"
  • During my time at Microsoft, I got a little more "business-y"
  • And that caused resentment from the tech folks - called "overhead"
  • Some sort of record: insulted by both sides!
  • Still technical! Took a week off entirely to code at one point

The challenge

  • Technology came naturally to me, people didn't
  • I explicitly took the challenge, going from dev to business as I joined Microsoft
  • Wasn't easy! Feedback of 'abrasive' at Microsoft!
  • People are harder to deal with than the code!

Student of human behavior

  • I needed to become a...
  • Treat it like a skill to be learned

You've got the hardware

  • We are systematic, logical thinkers
  • Debugging = collecting data, theorizing, testing
  • We've tuned our intuition for 'code smells'
  • We are systematic, logical thinkers
    • We think about entire systems, understand how one change will affect it
  • Debugging = collecting data, theorizing, testing
    • Tenacity. All have story of dogged determination.
    • Days! Many times through that cycle! Finally got it.
  • We've tuned our intuition for 'code smells'
    • By looking at lots and lots of code, we've trained low-level systems

Three C's of Communication

  • First, let's talk about the basic building blocks of dealing with humans

Clarity

  • Specifics (explain "probably" in detail)
  • Define terms
  • Summarize with paraphrasing
  • Agree on specific next steps
  • Send meeting notes
  • Define terms
    • story: Everett at Microsoft, early on
  • Summarize with paraphrasing ("I'm hearing...")
  • Agree on specific next steps
  • Send meeting notes
    • at Microsoft I used to take notes on the screen - real-time summary paraphrase!

  • Please send the email in a few days.

Caring

  • Facial expressions, tones of voice
  • Be less judgmental!
  • Don't preach; influence
  • The Platinum Rule
  • [now we need to assure people of our intentions - why I was 'abrasive' at MSFT?]
  • Facial expressions, tones of voice
    • You know you do it. Your frustration/disdain shows through
    • History of negative interactions? will take time to break through
    • We're really bad actors, so...
  • Be less judgmental!
    • "Your belief system is internally inconsistent, therefore I judge you"
    • Is your system fully consistent? Maybe they have some internal rationality?
  • Don't preach; influence
    • Can't appeal to some random authority
    • Need to influence by speaking their language, connect to their priorities
  • The Platinum Rule
    • A step better, and more difficult than the golden rule
    • Story: Asked for two-page stories for christmas because I already had too much stuff.
    • This isn't couples counseling
    • But, this book is The Platinum Rule for romantic relationships
    • How to express your love in a language your partner understands

    First, Seek Understanding

    • There's a theme with the 'Caring' - you need to understand them better

    Pay attention!

    • Build subconscious pattern recognition

      • Exercise: Pattern Recognition

      • Which code is higher quality? Why?
      • Didn't take that long to figure it out
      • It's not an innate skill - it's something you've worked on for a long time

      You already do this for people

      • You do this already
      • You were surprised when Han came back to help Luke in Episode 4, right?
      • Think of the last time you were surprised by something someone did...

      Make it deliberate!

      • switch companies/teams?
      • the more cultures, people and teams you work with, the more data, better the tuning
      • Now let's start to verbalize what we know subconsciously

      Build Mental Models

      • What kind of person are they?
      • What do they know? What don't they know?
      • What mindset might cause their current behavior?
      • What are they trying to achieve with X action? Generally?
      • What's the larger context?
        • Incentives
        • Deadlines
        • Manager's desires
        • Team
        • History
      • (start basic and general) What kind of person are they?
      • What do they know? What don't they know?
      • What mindset might cause their current behavior?
        • Example: someone cuts in front of you at grocery store. Why?
      • What are they trying to achieve with X action? Generally?
      • Consider larger context
        • Incentives
        • Deadlines
        • Manager's desires
        • Team
        • History

      Exercise: Build a mental model

      Why did Han Solo say "I know"?

      • Turn to a neighbor and come up with a theory
      • 2 minutes
      • Ask for hands raised: we've got some theories out there?

      Play this game with friends!

      • Movies, TV Shows, Books
      • Why did character X do Y?
      • Does that seem consistent with their character/world?
      • Any guesses about the writer? Their biases?
      • Can also consider public/historical figures

      Your biases

      • Your own biases are going to start coming to the fore here
      • You'll notice that you project onto others quite a lot
      • Maybe you initially assume everyone has negative intentions? They want status?
      • That's why it's good to bring in others: Friends, Mentors, etc.
      • Why we test those mental models!

      Testing Mental Models

      • Verify your assumptions: what they know, their larger context
      • Dig into their thought processes: "How did you approach X?"
      • Get more detail: "Tell me more about X"
      • Explore their self-image: "Why did you do X?" (repeat)
      • Get at core motivations:
        • Ask for recent, specific stories instead of hypotheticals
        • How they use time and money - an expression of priorities
      • Clarity: ask for terms to be defined, paraphrase back
        • Verify your assumptions: what they know, their larger context
        • Dig into their thought processes: "How did you approach X?"
        • Get more detail: "Tell me more about X"
        • Explore their self-image: "Why did you do X?" (repeat)
        • Get at core motivations:
          • Ask for recent, specific stories instead of hypotheticals

        • [Important to do this 1 on 1; no cross-talk]

      Exercise: Build and Test

      • First, find someone who uses a different Code Editor
      • Take 1 minute to Build a Mental Model
      • Each take 90 seconds for Testing
      • [Remember no judging!]
      • Ask for hands raised: ask for summaries of what they found
      • Anyone surprised by answers to questions? Why?
      • Any biases discovered?

      Now what?

      • That communicate, build, test loop: feedback system to improve skills
      • What can you eventually do with it?
      • Story: Dev10 SP1 - 2000-person project
      • Held focus group to provide details of branch/process to dev/QA.

      Summary

      • Become a student of human behavior
      • First, seek understanding
        • Pay attention: tune intuition with lots of data
        • Build mental models: consider knowledge, context
        • Understand some of your own biases
        • Test mental models: validate assumptions, motivations
      • Communicate well - three C's
        • Clarity: specifics, next steps
        • Confidence: posture, eye contact
        • Caring: the platinum rule, judge less
